Posts.Content: I am a stage III melanoma cancer survivor and I, too, had developed an odor under the arm.  It was different thay typical BO and yet, I cannot describe it. My clothes also sometimes retained the smell. It went away after my surgeries and treatment. Our dog at the time also sensed it, I am sure. She became overly protective of me for about the year before being diagnosed - to a point where she showed her teeth if someone were to approach me.  Unfortunately, we had two young girls at the time and we felt we had to get rid of the dog because of my upcoming surgeries and treatment. How would anyone ever get close to me to help?  Sadly, during the yearlong treatment, I happen to catch a tv special focusing on the ability of golden retrievers to sense melanoma. It was said that the dog senses it like it would an injured puppy.  Our dog must have known and was protecting me because of that.
Posts.Title: Cancer smell

Posts.Content: Just to add to my post about melanoma - my primary was on my knee and my affected lymph nodes were in my groin. The cancer was no where near my underarms where the smell was originating from.
Posts.Title: Cancer smell

Posts.Content: Hi Jenn, I am sorry you have to wait so long for your ultrasound. The anxiety of the wait is torture for the mind, for sure. Sometimes our bodies tell us that something is amiss in various ways. I hope your body is trying to say something much less serious than cancer.
Posts.Title: Cancer smell
